title: ’A knock on the door changed my life forever’
text:
Share on Twitter 
REBECCA Poulson never thought the knock on the door on her birthday would be the end of her life as she knew it. 
She woke up the morning of September 15, 2003 as a 33-year-old with a tight-knit family and by the time she went to bed it was all torn apart. 
She heard a police officer’s voice come through her intercom but she thought it had something to do with her brother-in-law breaching his AVO against her sister again. 
It had happened so many times already, including the night before. 
As Ms Poulson rolled her eyes at the fact he broke the AVO again, she knew immediately that this time was not like the others. 
Her heart pounded loudly in her ears after she was told her brother-in-law murdered her father and niece and nephew. 
Her father Peter Poulson was babysitting four-year-old Malee and Bas, who was almost two, at a home in Wilberforce, northwest of Sydney. 
Ms Poulson had already lost her brother Adrian to suicide, but nothing had prepared her for the brutal attack on those she loved more than anything. 
As police pulled up to the Wilberforce home, three people were laying in the driveway with blood over the cement. Neung Kongsom had the knife raised as police jumped out of the car and shot him. He later died. Peter Poulson, holding his grandchildren Malee and Bas. Source: News Limited 
This is a nightmare unimaginable for many, but for Ms Poulson this is her reality. Having lived it herself, she now fights against the horror of domestic violence. 
At the end of this month, Ms Poulson will speak out at the National Family Violence Summit in Canberra about the lack of understanding around domestic violence and what needs to change. 
Not only was Ms Poulson’s sister a victim of domestic violence, but she herself also suffered 
from having an abusive partner. 
He would pinch and twist her skin and push and shove her around. At first, she didn’t even realise she was being abused. 
“Domestic violence is not just full-on punching,” she told news.com.au. 
“You have emotional, psychological and sexual abuse as well and some of it is hard to pinpoint.” 
Ms Poulson said if a man told a woman what to wear or texted her 50 times a day, he could be an abusive partner because he was controlling. 
People who are put down or criticised by their partners could also be victims of domestic violence. 
Ms Poulson said her partner would criticise her for how she would maintain the house and her parenting skills. 
The terrifying thing about violent partners is sometimes it’s not discovered until people are deep in relationships and often women in particular will fall in love with a charming persona before they turn evil and violent. 
In her book about her traumatic experiences with domestic violence, Killing Love , Ms Poulson says Kongsom was clever in the end. 
“He had outwitted us all. His threats had only ever been about self harm, which had us dancing attendance on him,” she wrote. 
“He knew it was a weak point; our family had been riddled with the guilt of Adrian’s suicide for ten years. 
“How gleeful and superior he must have felt as we handed Malee and Bas over to him, again and again ... we thought they were safe with him. Neung was claiming our lives too. His rage was seeping out.” Bas Kongsom. Picture: Jeff Herbert Source: News Corp Australia Malee Kongsom. .Picture: Jeff Herbert Source: News Corp Australia 
Ms Poulson’s main aim now is to teach children in schools about domestic violence and what it means to be in an abusive relationship and she said it wasn’t just the partners who suffered from domestic violence. 
“Right now there’s a kid in terror, which is heartbreaking,” Ms Poulson said. 
“There would be thousands of kids in terror and boys who see domestic violence are twice as likely to become abusive and girls become two or three times more likely to become a victim. 
“It’s a horrible cycle that we really need to break.” 
The general manager of community services at BaptistCare, the organisation sponsoring the summit held by the Tara Costigan Foundation, said the summit would give hope to people experiencing domestic violence. 
“This is not the theory of domestic violence, as important as those are, its not about the statistics, as compelling as they are, but a real human story you can’t walk away from,” Rob Ellis said. 
He admitted the problem could not be fixed overnight but said the summit was to work with women and children who were victims and men who had controlling behaviour. 
The National Family Violence Summit will be on the 28th of February and 1st of March 2017 in Canberra. 
If you or someone you know is impacted by family violence, call 1800 RESPECT (1800 737 732) or visit www.1800RESPECT.org.au. 
You can also call Lifeline on 131114 or chat online at www.lifeline.org.au
